Ladies and gentlemen, esteemed colleagues in the Ministry of Education,

Let me begin by acknowledging the challenges we all face. Our system is strained, our resources are finite, and the demand for quality education is rising. We are expected to cater to every child, regardless of their ability or background. But let me ask you—can we truly serve all, when only a few will ever truly benefit?

The data is clear: not all children are equally capable of academic success. Some struggle with basic literacy, while others show exceptional promise. The truth is, we cannot afford to waste our precious resources on those who will never contribute meaningfully to our nation’s future. It is a harsh reality, but one we must face with courage and pragmatism.

This is where the concept of early labor integration becomes not only beneficial, but necessary. By allowing—no, encouraging—certain students to enter the workforce at an early age, we relieve the burden on our schools. We free up classrooms, teachers, and funds for those who are truly capable of excelling. The children who are not academically inclined find their place in the labor market, where they can contribute to the economy and, in turn, support their families. It is a win for everyone.

We must not be blinded by sentimentality. We are not a charity. We are a government body tasked with the efficient use of public resources. It is irresponsible to pour millions into educating a child who will never graduate, when that same money could fund scholarships for the gifted.

Some may call this approach harsh or even cruel. I say it is honest. It is a recognition of the real world. If we continue to pretend that every child can succeed in a classroom, we are not helping them—we are failing them. We are creating a system that is unsustainable and unjust to the truly deserving.

Let us be bold. Let us not coddle the incapable. Let us channel our efforts and our funds into those who will rise. The rest will find their path in the workforce, and that is not a tragedy—it is a necessity.

Together, we can build a more efficient, more effective education system. One that is not weighed down by false hopes and unrealistic expectations. One that serves the future of our nation, not the past of our ideals.

Thank you.
